mission.title: Our Mission
mission.body: We engineer in-vitro models of human organ systems to reveal how cancer cells respond to physical, chemical, and biological cues. By integrating engineering principles with cancer biology, our work enables the development of scalable translational models that empower oncologists to make informed, personalized treatment decisions.
points: Quantify forces and flows in tumor microenvironments

mission.title: Our Approach
mission.body: We combine advanced engineering tools with biological insight to bridge the gap between model systems and clinical needs. Our designs include custom equipment that integrates seamlessly with standard laboratory tools, enhancing experimental precision and scalability.
points: Microfluidics for flow, 3D bioprinting for architecture, and traction microscopy for mechanics

topics.title: Microscope Enabled 3D-Bioprinting
topics.summary: Our custom 3D bioprinting system integrates a precision printing head with an inverted microscope, giving us direct visual feedback during fabrication. Python-based control coordinates the XY stage, Z-axis needle movement, and three independently driven syringe pumps, enabling multi-resolution bioink delivery. This level of control allows accurate placement of diverse materials to create high-fidelity, biologically relevant structures.

topics.title: Microfluidic Systems
topics.summary: We design microfluidic chips to support advanced in vitro tissue models. Using our GELS platform, cells within these chips self-assemble into organized tissue constructs. Carefully engineered channel dimensions maintain a passive, steady flow that supplies nutrients and removes waste without external pumps—sustaining healthy, functional tissues over extended periods.

story.text: This chip supports the development of complex tissue architectures, as well as tissue explants.

topics.title: Traction Force Microscopy
topics.summary: Our 3D traction force microscopy technique quantifies how cells exert forces at the gel interface of granular hydrogels. By mapping these forces in three dimensions, we gain insight into the mechanical processes that drive cells to remodel their surroundings and self-organize into complex, composite tissue structures.

projects.title: Open Microfluidic Syringe Pump
projects.summary: We are developing an open microfluidic syringe pump that combines precise temperature control with multi-channel flow delivery. The system can heat or cool bioinks and culture media in real time, ensuring optimal conditions throughout experiments. Designed for seamless integration with microfluidic chips, it enables on-demand droplet generation and supports a wide range of advanced tissue engineering and cell culture applications.

projects.title: Auto In-Vitro platform
projects.summary: Our automated in-vitro device maintains and monitors cell cultures in a standard well plate format. A cooled reservoir keeps media and reagents fresh, while an integrated 3D printing module enables continuous fabrication directly into the culture environment. Coupled with real-time imaging from an integrated microscope, the system supports long-term experiments with minimal manual intervention.

grad.name: Gabriel Declerq
grad.bio: I am a biomedical engineer and first-year PhD student specializing in device design and interdisciplinary research. As a 2025 UROC Mentor and 2025 Star Labs Mentor, I guide emerging scientists while leading multiple research initiatives, including CELLS, TF-ELISA, Spatial Growth Factor Release in LLS, and Syringe Pump development. My work bridges engineering innovation with biomedical applications to advance scientific discovery and practical healthcare solutions.

grad.name: Cason Hancock
grad.bio: I’m a third-year PhD student in the Cancer Biology Graduate Interdisciplinary Program at the University of Arizona. With degrees in Biochemistry (Centenary College of Louisiana) and Biomedical Engineering (Columbia University), my work bridges engineering and cancer biology. I focus on developing advanced in-vitro tools, currently combining in-situ bead-based ELISA with Raman Spectroscopy for non-invasive, real-time measurements of changes in the tumor microenvironment. My goal is to become a Principal Investigator, creating innovative ways to profile and manipulate cancer to improve patient outcomes. Outside the lab, I enjoy ultimate frisbee, cooking, exploring new music, and discovering Tucson.
